awd_titl_txt: Taking Supramolecular Assembly to the Next Level: Assembly of Flexible Molecules with Complex Internal Structure and Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Karl Freed of the University of Chicago is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to investigate equilibrium self-assembly of molecules into non-covalently bonded ordered supramolecular structures.  This phenomenon is pervasive in chemistry, materials science, and biology, and its control has numerous applications in industry and medicine.  Earlier studies elucidated general underlying principles of this spontaneous and reversible organization based on models that ignored details of the internal structure of the molecules. The current work is extending those theoretical advances to account for the strong and often subtle influence of the chemical structure of the assembling units, their geometrical shapes, and their mutual (often directional) interactions.  The Lattice Cluster Theory formalism developed earlier is being generalized to include (i) strong and/or attractive interactions and (ii) flexible/deformable molecules.  The goal is to describe five qualitatively different types of self-assembly of structured units, including assembly into chains and network structures.   The intramolecular and intermolecular structure and thermodynamics contributions are nonadditive, adding computational challenge but also relevance to realistic chemical association. This new class of self-assembly theories enables examination of the ubiquitous enthalpy-entropy compensation phenomenon, where modification of a system by what is anticipated to produces large changes in the enthalpy (of a reaction) is largely compensated by a corresponding change in the entropy (and vice versa).

The bottom-up manufacture of materials for applications in industry and medicine is made possible when molecules in solution come together and organize spontaneously.  The circumstances under which this occurs have become clearer from the work of Freed and his group, who are developing computational tools describing the chemical association of neighboring molecules in this process of equilibrium self-assembly.  Different structures may result, for example, chains and network structures, and the outcomes can be influenced by the shapes and vibrating and rotating behavior of the individual molecules.  The goals of the work are to understand how different outcomes occur for different molecules and to use this knowledge to control self-assembly so that it can be fully exploited in bottom-up material design.

The self-assembly of molecules to form large clusters under equilibrium condition is a ubiquitous phenomenon that is widely recognized in physics, chemistry, and biology. Recent progress in the synthesis of supramolecular polymer materials provides a striking example of the practical relevance of self-assembly in designing new high tech materials. These advances in the experimental control, analysis, and molecular synthesis couple with pressing societal needs for the development of advanced materials for energy, transportation, and environmental remediation (such as waste water cleanup and more environmentally sustainable and versatile polymer materials) and with the desire for more efficient a priori design and control of molecular chemistry to provide increased impetus for understanding how chemical structure relates to the phase stability of polymer materials and supramolecular assemblies.

 

Understanding of self-assembly processes has, however, been slow to develop since the initial work in this area more than a century ago. Hence, a major focus of our NSF supported research has been to develop analytically tractable theories for the dependence on molecular structures and interactions of a wide variety of molecular systems that self-assembly under equilibrium conditions and/or whose propensity for dissolving (i.e., being “solvated”) or precipitating from solutions involves equilibrium self-assembly. The research outlines a broad theoretical framework for developing theories of equilibrium self-assembly that can assist in the rational design of new materials, thereby contributing to the broad goals of the recent Materials Genome Initiative and to the needs for the design of new drug systems and physical therapies to mitigate against diseases associated with malfunctioning self-assembly. Our research should also stimulate new experiments and initiatives in computer simulations, and the free availability of the computer programs and codes developed during the proposed research will facilitate and synchronize these activities.

 

Our focus has centered on more complex self-assembly processes and, therefore, has been directed to systems of relevance to those that often appear in biology, drug design, and manufacturing applications and that lead to the formation of new patterns of thermodynamics. Examples include self-assembly in a polymer matrix or in the presence of adsorbing boundaries, and the self-assembly by mutual association of two distinct species. Also studied by us are the origins of re-entrant self-assembly transitions, stress relaxation in a self-assembling fluid, the analogy between self-assembly and glass-formation, the influence of added structured diluents to glass-formation in polymers, a precursor to modeling glass formation in self-assembling systems. While our earlier studies have been devoted to systems for which adequate theories may ignore the complex internal molecular structure of the self-assembling species, we are increasingly extending the theories to describe specific molecular influences of equilibrium self-assembly.

 

Our research addresses some of the most basic problems in the statistical thermodynamics of polymers, specifically problems associated with understanding a) how details of monomer molecular structure relate to the thermodynamic stability of polymer materials (in homopolymer mixtures and solutions of supramolecular complexes) and b) how association with the solvent affects the phase stability of the self-assembling systems.
